questions.question: Which of the following marked structures is the space of Gillette?
An ENT surgeon is performing an incision and drainage for a retropharyngeal abscess due tosuppurative lymphadenitis. Which among the following groups of lymph nodes is most likelyto be involved?
questions.explanation: Rouvier Nodes or retropharyngeal lymph nodes suppurate to form retropharyngeal abscess.Each lateral compartment of retropharyngeal space contains lymph nodes that usually disappearat 3-4 years of age. Suppuration of these lymph nodes is the most common cause ofretropharyngeal space abscess in children.Option B - Delphian nodes are the pre-laryngeal lymph nodes.Option C - Virchow's node is the left supraclavicular lymph node.Option D - Cloquet's nodes are the deep inguinal lymph nodes.

questions.question: 480A concerned mother brought her toddler to the ER with complaints of noisy breathing andthe child refusing to feed. On examination, the child has adenoid facies and there is a bulge inthe posterior pharyngeal wall lateral to the midline. Which of the following is a falsestatement regarding the disease described above?

options.A: Suppuration of nodes of Rouvier can cause the above condition
options.B: Caries of the cervical spine is the most common cause
options.C: In adults similar condition may result from penetrating injury of the cervical esophagus
options.D: Torticollis is one of the symptoms.

questions.explanation: The above clinical condition is suggestive of acute retropharyngeal abscess whereas caries of thecervical spine results in a chronic retropharyngeal abscess.Acute retropharyngeal abscess is commonly seen in children below 3 years. It is the result ofsuppuration of retropharyngeal lymph nodes secondary to infection in the adenoids, nasopharynx,posterior nasal sinuses, or nasal cavity.In adults, it may result from penetrating injury of the posterior pharyngeal wall or cervicalesophagus.Clinical features of a retropharyngeal abscess include•Dysphagia and difficulty in breathing - as the abscess obstructs the air and food passages.Stridor and croupy cough• Torticollis - the neck becomes stiff and the head is kept extended.• A bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall, usually seen on one side of the midline.Chronic retropharyngeal abscess is the result of•Caries of the cervical spine⚫ Tuberculous infection of retropharyngeal lymph nodes secondary to tuberculosis of deep cervicalnodes.

questions.question: A 42-year-old HIV-positive man presents with an acute onset of high-grade fever with chills and shortness of breath. On evaluation, he is diagnosed with a necrotizing mediastinitis secondary to the rupture of a retropharyngeal abscess. What is the likely route of spread of infection to the mediastinum?

options.A: Between the buccopharyngeal fascia and alar fascia.
options.B: Between the alar fascia and prevertebral fascia
options.C: Between the capsule of the tonsil and superior constrictor muscle
options.D: Between the prevertebral fascia and vertebrae

questions.explanation: The likely route of spread of infection is between the alar fascia anteriorly and the prevertebral fascia posteriorly. It is also called the danger space or alar space. It lies just posterior to the retropharyngeal space. It extends from the skull base to the diaphragm. Infections from this space can spread to the mediastinum, and hence it is named the danger space.

questions.question: Given below is an X-ray of a child who presented with stridor. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given image is suggestive of a retropharyngeal abscess. It can be diagnosed on a lateral X-ray of the soft tissues of the neck. The features include: • Widening of the prevertebral soft tissue shadow • Loss of cervical lordosis • In an acute abscess, air-fluid levels can be seen.

questions.question: Which of the following options is synonymous with quinsy?
questions.explanation: Quinsy is synonymous with peritonsillar abscess.It is the collection of pus between the fibrous capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictormuscles of the pharynx.

questions.question: A middle-aged diabetic man who had undergone a tooth extraction presents with fever andtrismus. On examination, his posterior pillar is pushed medially and there is a swelling in theneck at the upper 1/3rd of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The clinical scenario is suggestive of parapharyngeal abscess.Parapharyngeal abscess presents with:Trismus due to spasm of medial pterygoid• Tonsils pushed medially• Swelling in the upper part of the sternocleidomastoid (space limited to the level of hyoid bone).-Option A Retropharyngeal abscess presents as a bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall on oneside of the midline.Option C - In Ludwig's angina, tonsils are not pushed medially.Option D - Peritonsillar abscess doesn't produce swelling in the upper 1/3rd of thesternocleidomastoid.

questions.question: Which of the following is not synonymous with parapharyngeal abscess?
questions.explanation: Parapharyngeal abscess is not synonymous with medial pharyngeal abscess.Parapharyngeal abscess is synonymous with pharyngomaxillary or lateral pharyngeal orpterygomaxillary abscess.489

questions.question: Which of the following is correct regarding a parapharyngeal abscess?482

options.A: Always spreads from the retropharyngeal space
options.C: It has preponderance for male gender

questions.explanation: Parapharyngeal abscess has a preponderance for male gender.Parapharyngeal abscess is an emergency condition. Infection can spread to the parapharyngealspace from any of the other deep neck spaces - peritonsillar, retropharyngeal and submandibularspaces. It commonly spreads from a dental infection, tonsillitis or peritonsillar abscesses. Thepatient is usually systemically unwell, with severe trismus and possibly airway compromise.Initial broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics should include cover against streptococci andanaerobic organisms.Carotid sheath vessel thrombosis, necrotizing fasciitis and mediastinitis are some of thecomplications.Marked neck swelling, airway compromise, and male gender appear to be predictive of higher-riskcases.

questions.question: Which of the following features will not be manifested in an infection of the post-styloidcompartment of the parapharyngeal space?
questions.explanation: Trismus is not a feature of infection of the post-styloid compartment of the parapharyngeal space.Trismus is seen in pre-styloid abscess due to the involvement of medial pterygoid muscle.Parapharyngeal space is divided into two compartments by the styloid process and itsattachments. Clinical features depend on the compartment involved.In a post-styloid abscess, there is a bulge of the pharynx behind the posterior pillar, accompaniedby paralysis of cranial nerves IX, X (resulting in vocal cord paralysis), XI, XII, and the sympatheticchain, which can manifest as Horner's syndrome. Swelling in the parotid region may also bepresent. Notably, trismus, the inability to fully open the mouth, is usually absent in this type ofabscess.A pre-styloid abscess exhibits distinct features including the prolapse of the tonsil and tonsillarfossa, along with trismus caused by the spasm of the medial pterygoid muscle. Markedodynophagia is common. Additionally, an external swelling can be observed behind the angle ofthe jaw.Fever, sore throat, torticollis (caused by spasm of the prevertebral muscles), and signs of systemictoxicity are common features.Diagnosis can be established using a contrast-enhanced CT scan (CECT). If there is suspicion ofthrombosis of the internal jugular vein or an aneurysm of the internal carotid artery, magneticresonance arteriography (MRA) can be useful.Patients require intravenous antibiotic therapy with amoxicillin-clavulanic acid, carbapenemantibiotics plus drugs that target anaerobic organisms, such as clindamycin or metronidazole. Aparapharyngeal abscess is drained by an external horizontal incision made on the skin a fewcentimeters below the angle of the mandible.The image attached below shows the components of both spaces:490Pre-styloid and Post-styloid components ofParapharyngeal sapceMaxillaPost-styloidcompartment=PrestyloidfatPre-styloidcompartmentMandibleStyloid processCarotid sheathCervical sympathetic chainOMARROWBoth lobeof parotid

questions.question: In which of the following clinical scenarios will you not perform an intraoral incision?

options.A: A 21-year-old woman with fever, hot potato voice and bulging of soft palate and anterior pillarabove the tonsil on the right side.
options.B: A 50-year-old diabetic man with fever, neck swelling over upper rd of the leftsternocleidomastoid and the tonsils on the same side pushed medially
options.C: A 3-year-old child with fever and swelling in the posterior pharyngeal wall lateral to the midline
options.D: A 50-year-old man with fever due to penetrating injury of oral mucosa by wood splinters

questions.explanation: An intraoral incision is not sufficient in the case of option B - parapharyngeal abscess. An externalneck incision must be made always to ensure complete drainage of the abscess.Option A- This is a case of quinsy as the child has odynophagia and a hot potato voice.Option B - This is a case of parapharyngeal abscess as the swelling is in the upper 1/3rd of theneck and the tonsil of the same side is pushed mediallyOption C- This is a case of retropharyngeal abscess since there is fever and swelling in theposterior pharyngeal wall lateral to the midline.Option D- This is a case of Sublingual abscess involving the sublingual space which is caused bypenetrating injuries of oral mucosa due to fishbone or wood splinters.Indications for Incision and Drainage:Sublingual abscess: Always intraoral incision• Parapharyngeal abscess: Always external neck incision.••• Peritonsillar abscess: Always intraoral.⚫ Retropharyngeal abscess:• Intraoral - in rose position• External - Dean approach.Ludwig's angina:•Intraoral if the infection is still localized to sublingual space.• External-if the infection involves submaxillary space.491

questions.question: A 9-year-old boy comes with complaints of right ear pain, difficulty in opening the mouth,painful swallowing, and fever. The oral cavity examination reveals the following. The externalfacial examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is likely?483

options.B: Parotid abscessBezold's Abscessd) QuinsyQuestion 13:Which of the following statements about quinsy is false?a) Collection of pus between the capsule of tonsil and superior constrictorb) Presents with odynophagia and drooling of saliva

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario describes a child with fever, otalgia, trismus, and odynophagia with anormal external facial examination. The oral cavity shows congested and edematous tonsil andtonsillar pillars with edematous uvula pushed to the opposite side. These findings are highlysuggestive of quinsy (peritonsillar abscess).It is the collection of pus in the peritonsillar space between the fibrous capsule of the tonsil andthe superior constrictor muscles of the pharynx. Both aerobic and anaerobic organisms are seen.Patient presents with fever, unilateral throat pain, odynophagia, hot potato voice, torticollis, foulbreath, referred otalgia through glossopharyngeal nerve and trismus due to spasm of pterygoidmuscles.Oral cavity examination may show congested and edematous tonsils, pillars, and soft palate on theinvolved side. Edematous uvula pushed to the opposite side. Pus may be seen on the tonsillarregion. Jugulodigastric lymph nodes may be enlarged.The management of quinsy is by antibiotics and incision and drainage to drain the abscessfollowed by interval tonsillectomy 4 to 6 weeks later.Rare complications seen are parapharyngeal abscess, edema of the larynx, septicemia, lungabscess, or jugular vein thrombosis.Other options:Option A: Pharyngitis presents with fever, throat pain, enlarged tonsils, and lymphoid follicles onthe posterior pharyngeal wall.Option B: Parotid abscess occurs due to the suppuration of parotid space. It presents withswelling, redness, firmness, and tenderness in the parotid area and at the angle of the mandible. Itis usually unilateral, but bilateral abscesses can occur. Due to the thick capsule, fluctuation isoften difficult to elicit.Option C: Bezold abscess is a complication of acute otomastoiditis where the infection/pus breaksthrough the thin medial side of the tip of the mastoid and presents as a swelling in the upper partof the neck.

questions.question: A 16-year-old girl presented with complaints of fever, right-sided throat pain, and difficulty inswallowing. On examination, she had hot potato speech and halitosis. The right tonsil was notvisualised due to oedematous pillars and the uvula was pushed to the left. How willmanage this patient?you
questions.explanation: The above clinical scenario is suggestive of peritonsillar abscess or quinsy and managementinvolves incision and drainage with antibiotics.Management of quinsy⚫ Hospitalization• Intravenous fluids to combat dehydration• Antibiotics Suitable antibiotics in large IV doses to cover aerobes and anaerobes•Analgesics•-Drainage by needle aspiration or incision and drainage• Tonsillectomy when there is airway obstruction or recurrence.Incision and drainage of the abscess: A peritonsillar abscess is opened at the point of themaximum bulge above the upper pole of the tonsil or just lateral to the point of junction of theanterior pillar with a line drawn through the base of the uvula.

questions.question: In a patient with recurrent peritonsillar abscess, when is the ideal time to perform atonsillectomy?
questions.explanation: In a patient with recurrent peritonsillar abscess (quinsy), ideally, an interval tonsillectomy is done4-6 weeks after the infection settles down.Hot tonsillectomy: Earlier tonsillectomy was done during incision and drainage. But this is notfollowed now as it is dangerous and can lead to aspiration, bleeding & spread of infection.

questions.question: A patient presents with complaints of pain while swallowing since 2 days. He also gives ahistory of toothache since 1 week. On examination, there is a swelling and erythema as in thefigure below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The above clinical scenario is suggestive of Ludwig's angina.Ludwig's angina is an infection of the submandibular space which lies between the mucousmembrane of the floor of the mouth and tongue on one side and the superficial layer of deepcervical fascia extending between the hyoid bone and mandible on the other.

questions.question: Which of the following is a false statement about Ludwig's angina?

options.A: It involves both sublingual and submandibular spaces
options.C: Dental infections are the most common cause
options.D: H. influenza is the most common organism implicated.

questions.explanation: Mixed infection with aerobes and anaerobes is seen in Ludwig's angina. Among these, alpha-hemolytic streptococci, staphylococci, and Bacteroides groups are common. Ludwig's angina is an infection of the submandibular space. The space is divided into two compartments by the mylohyoid muscle: the sublingual compartment (above the mylohyoid) and the submandibular and submental compartment (below the mylohyoid). The two compartments are continuous around the posterior border of the mylohyoid muscle. Both compartments freely communicate in the midline with the opposite side. Therefore, infection rapidly becomes bilateral. The most common cause of Ludwig's angina is dental infections (accounting for 80% of cases).

questions.question: A 23-year-old man presents to the OPD with odynophagia and swelling. He is diagnosed withLudwig's angina. How might you describe the swelling?

options.A: Tender fluctuant swelling in the floor of mouth
options.B: Tender fluctuant swelling in the parotid region
options.C: Woody hard swelling in the floor of mouth
options.D: Woody hard swelling in the parotid region

questions.explanation: Ludwig's angina presents as a tender woody hard swelling on the floor of the mouth.There can be marked difficulty in swallowing (odynophagia) with varying degrees of trismus. Thetongue is progressively pushed upwards and backward, threatening the airway. Laryngeal edemamay also be present.Usually, there is cellulitis of the tissues rather than frank abscess. Incision and drainage showsalted pork appearance.

questions.question: A 50-year-old man with multiple comorbidities, post-op day 5 of major abdominal surgeryhas developed high-grade fever and swelling over the parotid area. On examination, there istenderness, induration and pus exuding from the Stenson's duct on applying pressure overthe parotids. Which of the following options is not a likely cause for the above condition?
questions.explanation: The above clinical scenario is suggestive of a parotid abscess and excessive gland stimulation isnot a cause for its formation.Etiology of Parotid Abscess:• Dehydration, particularly in postsurgical cases (5-7 post-op days) and debilitated patients, withstasis of salivary flow is the predisposing cause.• Infection from the oral cavity travels via the Stenson's duct to invade the parotid gland(retrograde spread of infection). The most common organism is Staphylococcus aureus butStreptococci, anaerobic organisms, and rarely the gram negative organisms have also beencultured.

questions.question: A patient with a parotid abscess is planned for incision and drainage (I & D). Which ofthe following practices will you avoid in this patient?

options.A: Put an incision that is similar to parotidectomy
options.B: Blunt dissection of the pus pockets
options.C: Dissection parallel to the facial nerve branches
options.D: Wait for the swelling to become fluctuant before performing I & D486

questions.explanation: In a case of a parotid abscess, one must never wait for fluctuation or pus point to occur. This isbecause the superficial layer of parotidomasseteric fascia is tense and the fluctuation will beapparent only in later stages.A parotid abscess refers to an infection and pus formation in the parotid space. It is caused mostcommonly by Staphylococcus aureus. Post-surgical cases and debilitated patients with stasis ofsalivary flow are at risk of developing parotid abscesses.Patients typically present with unilateral swelling, redness, induration, and tenderness over theparotid gland and angle of the mandible. Dehydration and fever are also present. Diagnosis is byultrasonography or a CT scan. Multiple small loculi of pus are seen in the parenchyma. Aspirationof abscess can be done to determine the culture and sensitivity of the infective agent.494Correction of dehydration, improving oral hygiene and promoting salivary flow. Intravenousantibiotics are also used in treatment.Surgical drainage under local or general anesthesia is carried out by a preauricular incision asemployed for parotidectomy. A skin flap is raised to expose the surface of the gland, and theabscess or abscesses are bluntly opened working parallel to the branches of the VIIth nerve. Theskin incision is loosely approximated over a drain and allowed to heal by secondary intention.495
